title: 108_hr2601
content: The "Public Domain Enhancement Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The findings section of the Act is also included. The Congress finds that the copyright clause in the United States Constitution grants Congress the power to promote the progress of science and arts by securing exclusive rights to authors for limited times, providing an economic incentive for creating and disseminating ideas. "The copyright term is limited to prevent permanent deprivation of the public from an artist's work. Both commercial and noncommercial creators rely on a healthy public domain." Both commercial and noncommercial creators benefit from a healthy public domain, using it for various purposes such as publishing titles, creating new productions, and generating materials for schools, museums, and libraries. The public domain is utilized by schools, museums, and libraries for educational and cultural materials. Media sources like the World Wide Web also benefit from public domain content. Current copyright law protects works from 1923 onwards, but older works are often no longer commercially available. Older works between 55 and 75 years old may not retain commercial value but can still be useful for historians, artists, and teachers. However, current copyright laws prevent these abandoned works from entering the public domain for many years, hindering their potential for building upon and preserving by commercial and noncommercial entities. The existing copyright system hinders abandoned works from entering the public domain, contrary to the intent of the Framers of the Constitution and Congress. It is necessary to establish a mechanism for abandoned American copyrights to enter the public domain. Establishing a maintenance fee for published United States works is necessary to allow abandoned American copyrights to enter the public domain. The definition of "United States work" in section 101 of title 17, United States Code, is amended for sections 306 and 411. Section 302 of title 17, United States Code, is amended for works created on or after January 1, 1978, regarding the duration of copyright. Section 303(a) of title 17, United States Code, is amended for works created but not published before January 1, 1978, by updating the language regarding copyright in subsections (A) and (B). Section 304 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to update language regarding copyright, including changes to subsection (a) for subsisting copyrights. Section 304 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to update language regarding copyright, including changes to subsection (a) for subsisting copyrights. In paragraph (1), subparagraphs (B) and (C) are modified by inserting "Subject to section 306, in" before certain phrases. In paragraph (2), subparagraph (A) is amended by adding "other than a copyright that expires under section 306," after a specific clause. In subsection (b), the language is updated to include "Subject to section 306" before certain clauses. In subsection (c), maintenance fees are addressed in Chapter 3 of title 17, United States Code. The Register of Copyrights charges a $1 fee for maintaining the copyright of published United States works. The fee is due 50 years after first publication or on December 31, 2004, and every 10 years thereafter until the end of the copyright term. The maintenance fee for maintaining copyright in the US is due 50 years after first publication or on December 31, 2004, and every 10 years thereafter. Failure to pay the fee within a 6-month grace period will result in the copyright expiring. Ancillary or promotional works connected to the main work will also be maintained if the copyright is renewed. The maintenance fee for copyright in the US is due every 10 years after the initial 50 years or by December 31, 2004. Failure to pay within a 6-month grace period will result in copyright expiration. Ancillary works related to the main work will also be maintained upon renewal. The form for the maintenance fee must conform to section 409 and can be used for registration under sections 408 and 409. The maintenance fee for published United States works is amended under section 708(a) of title 17, United States Code. This includes a new maintenance fee requirement under section 306. The Register of Copyrights must establish procedures to simplify the submission of forms under section 306(c) of title 17, US Code, and make the information easily accessible to the public within 12 months of this Act's enactment.
